taAllocation

Class Predicate

  • java.lang.Object
    • taAllocation.Predicate

  • public class Predicate
extends java.lang.Object
    Represents a predicate of the form predicate-name ( param , ... )

    Copyright: Copyright (c) 2005-2006, Department of Computer Science, University of Calgary. Permission to use, copy, modify, distribute and sell this software and its documentation for any purpose is hereby granted without fee, provided that the above copyright notice appear in all copies and that both that copyright notice and this permission notice appear in supporting documentation. The Department of Computer Science makes no representations about the suitability of this software for any purpose. It is provided "as is" without express or implied warranty.

    Author:
    Rob Kremer

    • Constructor Detail

      • Predicate

        Predicate(java.lang.String s)
    throws java.text.ParseException
        Constructs a predicate from s. If s is malformed, throws a ParseException exception. Describes errors by printing to System.out.
        Parameters:
        s - a String from which to parse the predicate data.
        Throws:
        java.text.ParseException - thrown if the string is malformed.

    • Method Detail

      • scanList

        private java.util.Vector<Pair<Predicate.ParamType,java.lang.Object>> scanList(java.lang.String list,
                                                                    Predicate.Int curInt,
                                                                    char terminator,
                                                                    char separator)
                                                                       throws java.text.ParseException
        Scans a parameter list or a list of set elements and returns a vector of pairs (type x value).
        Parameters:
        list - the input String.
        curInt - the index at which to start scanning the string.
        terminator - the character that will terminate the input.
        separator - the character that separates the input elements.
        Returns:
        a vector of (type x value) representing the list elements.
        Throws:
        java.text.ParseException - if the input list is malformed.

      • getArity

        public int getArity()
        Returns the number of paramteres.
        Returns:
        the number of parameters of this predicate. Note that an empty predcate (eg. "hot()" still has arity of 1 (a empty string parameter).

      • getParamType

        public Predicate.ParamType getParamType(int index)
        Returns the ParamType of the parameter at index. Note that index should be less than the value returned by getArity(). The first parameter is at index 0.
        Parameters:
        index - an index into the vector of parameters.
        Returns:
        a ParamType representing the type of the parameter.

      • getStringParam

        public java.lang.String getStringParam(int index)
        Returns the value of a string parameter at index index. If the index is out of range or the parameter is not of a string type, returns null.
        Parameters:
        index - the index of the parameter to evaluate
        Returns:
        a String representing the value of parameter at the index, or null.

      • getSetParam

        public java.util.TreeSet<Pair<Predicate.ParamType,java.lang.Object>> getSetParam(int index)
        Returns the value of a set parameter at index index as a TreeSet<Pair<ParamType,Object<<. Thus, nested sets are allowed. If the index is out of range or the parameter is not of a set type, returns null.
        Parameters:
        index - the index of the parameter to evaluate
        Returns:
        a TreeSet representing the value of parameter at the index, or null.

      • getLongParam

        public java.lang.Long getLongParam(int index)
        Returns the value of a long integer parameter at index index. If the index is out of range or the parameter is not of a Long type, returns null.
        Parameters:
        index - the index of the parameter to evaluate
        Returns:
        a Long representing the value of parameter at the index, or null.

      • scanFor

        private static int scanFor(java.lang.String in,
          int startAt,
          java.lang.String chars)
        Scans for the first occurrance of any of the charcters in chars starting at startAt, and returns the index (from the beginning of string, not startAt). It will not pay attention to the any target charater that is preceded by a backslash. Thus, scanFor() can be used in conjunction with escape() and unescape() to guarentee that an unknown string can be parsed. For example, you need to deliniate an arbitraty string for future readin, but there may be further text after it. You can't just surround your string with {} because your string may contain } characters. Save your string, s, as s="{"+escape(s,"{}")+"}" you can safely use scanFor(s,1,"{}") to find the original terminating } deliminator. The expression: 
         unescape(s.substring(scanFor(s,0,"{")+1,scanFor(s,scanFor(s,0,"{"),"}")),"{}")
        successfully retrieves the original string, no matter what was in the origial string.
        Parameters:
        in -
        startAt -
        chars -
        Returns:
        the index of the first occurance of a char in chars or -1 if none of the chars in chars are in in
        See Also:
        casa.util.CASAUtil#unescape(String,String), casa.util.CASAUtil#escape(String,String)

      • fromQuotedString

        private static java.lang.String fromQuotedString(java.lang.String s,
                                int startAt)
                                          throws java.text.ParseException
        Given a String (as generated from casa.util.CASAUtil#toQuotedString(String)) returns a String without the enclosing quotes and with an escaped double-quotes restored (unescaped). Extra chars after the closing quote are ignored.
        Parameters:
        s - the quoted string to de-quote
        startAt - the position is s to start at
        Returns:
        an unquoted, unescaped string
        Throws:
        java.text.ParseException - if s can't be interpreted as a quoted string (eg: first non-white-space isn't '"') starting at startAt
        See Also:
        casa.util.CASAUtil#unescape(String, String)

      • unescape

        private static java.lang.String unescape(java.lang.String in,
                        java.lang.String escChars)
        Removes any backslash characters that had been added to in by a previous call to escape() with the same escChars. For example, casautil.unescape("\(\(\)\)","()") ==> "(())" unescape() always unescapes the backslash character, so unescape(x,"") is exactly the same as unescape(x,"\\").
        Note that escape() and unescape() reverse each others actions (if you start with escape). However escape applied a second time will re-encode the string (if there were some escaped charaters). This can be undone by two calls to unescape. Unescape applied to a string that has not been escaped may have unpredictable results. 
         code                      value of s
 s = "(())";               (())
 s =   escape(s,"()");     \(\(\)\)
 s = unescape(s,"()");     (())
 s =   escape(s,"()");     \(\(\)\)
 s =   escape(s,"()");     \\(\\(\\)\\)
 s = unescape(s,"()");     \(\(\)\)
 s = unescape(s,"()");     (())
        Parameters:
        in -
        escChars -
        Returns:
        the in string unescaped
        See Also:
        casa.util.CASAUtil#escape(String,String), casa.util.CASAUtil#scanFor(String,int,String)
